You select a story.&nbsp;<br /><br />It seems like a great story to print, but you highlight two sentences in the first paragraph that you think might be run-ons.<br /><br />You decide to learn more about run-on sentences and how you can fix them.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<table border=\"2\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><strong><span class=\"ju-normal\" style=\"color:black;font-family:lato,sans-serif;font-size:16px;\">First Draft</span><br /><br />Local Business Helps Pups Behave!</strong></p><p>Are you frustrated with your puppy&rsquo;s energetic approach to life?&nbsp; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 1; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; display: inline !important; float: none; background-color: rgba(242, 242, 242, 0.498039);\"> </span><strong>subject</strong> (tells who or what is performing the action the sentence is describing) and a <strong>verb</strong> (tells what the subject is doing or tells the condition or state of being<strong>).</strong><br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p>Training benefits every dog<br /><br />it also creates a bond between a pup and owner.</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"3"},"leftText":"<p>When two independent clauses are in the same sentence, they need to be joined by punctuation that is strong enough to connect them.<br /><br />A comma is <strong>not</strong> a strong enough form of punctuation to connect two independent clauses.<br /><br />You can connect independent clauses with a comma followed by a joining&nbsp;word&nbsp;such as <em>and</em>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<em>but</em>, or a semicolon.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><img alt=\"A diagram shows two parts of a sentence,  Independent clause 1 and independent clause 2.   These two parts need strong punctuation between them.  Careful!  A comma on it's own is not strong enough to connect independent clause 1 and independent clause 2.\" src=\"data:image/png;base64,\" /></p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"4"},"leftText":"<p>A <strong>run-on sentence</strong> is a sentence with two independent clauses that are not connected by strong enough punctuation<strong>.</strong><br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><img alt=\"The sentence &quot;puppies are cute they have lots of energy&quot; is a run-on sentence because there is no punctuation between the two independent clauses &quot;puppies are cute&quot; and &quot;they have lots of energy&quot;.   \" src=\"data:image/png;base64,\" /></p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":"0","delayRight":"0","audioPath":"5"},"leftText":"<p>The first sentence you highlighted from the story is:<br /><br /><span class=\"ju-examples\" style=\"color:#552656;font-family:tahoma;\">Training benefits every dog it also creates a bond between a dog and owner.</span><br /><br />It has two independent clauses that each have a subject and a verb<strong> </strong>and can stand alone.&nbsp;<br /><br />The independent clauses are not joined by any punctuation.<br /><br />This is a run-on sentence.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Two independent clauses that each have a subject and verb:</span></p><p><img alt=\"The first independent clause is Training benefits every dog.  Training is the subject and benefits is the verb.  The second independent clause is it also creates a bond between a dog and owner.  It is the subject and creates is the   verb.  There is no punctuation between them.\" src=\"data:image/png;base64,\" /><br /><br /><span class=\"ju-normal\" style=\"color:black;font-family:lato,sans-serif;font-size:16px;\"><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Punctuation?</span></span></p><p>No.&nbsp;</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":1,"delayStep":"0","delayRight":"0","audioPath":"6"},"leftText":"<table border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-powertip\" style=\"width:100%\"><thead><tr><th scope=\"col\">ASK YOURSELF:&nbsp; An independent clause should have a subject and verb and be able to stand on its own.&nbsp; If it does...</p><p>2.&nbsp; Does it have strong enough punctuation to join the clauses?&nbsp; It needs a semi-colon or a comma and a joining word such as <em>and.</em> &nbsp;&nbsp; If it does not have strong enough punctuation, it is a run-on.<br /><br /><img alt=\"\" src=\"/images/picture_it.png\" /><a href=\"S3_BUCKET_/CS33/2/AskYourself_Run-onsentences.pdf\" onclick=\"window.open(this.href, '', 'resizable=yes,status=no,location=no,toolbar=no,menubar=no,fullscreen=no,scrollbars=no,dependent=no,width=825,left=100,height=600,top=50'); No.&nbsp;</p><p>The punctuation is a comma without a joining word.<br /><br /><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">3.&nbsp; Is it a run-on?&nbsp; </span>Yes.</p><p>This is a comma splice.</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":1,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":"0","audioPath":"8"},"leftText":"<p>There are three ways you can fix a run-on sentence.<br /><br />1.&nbsp; Add end punctuation and a capital letter&nbsp;to create two sentences.<br />&nbsp;</p>","headerText":"How to fix a run-on","rightText":"<p>Training benefits every dog<span class=\"marker\"><span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\"> period</span>.&nbsp;<span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\"> Capital I, </span>I</span>t also creates a bond between a dog and owner.</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":"0","delayRight":"0","audioPath":"9"},"leftText":"<p>2.&nbsp; An independent clause should have a subject and verb and be able to stand on its own.&nbsp; If it does...</p><p>2.&nbsp; Does it have strong enough punctuation to join the clauses?&nbsp; It needs a semicolon or a comma and a joining word such as <em>and.</em> &nbsp;&nbsp;
